content: Good problem and correct difficulty level. It tooks me a bit of time to understand the statement (mainly the tree construction) but it's clear enough.

Interesting problem and clear statement.

However, I see a problem with the constraints about p and q : those constraints are only for the resulting fraction (path=> fraction problem) not for the given fraction (fraction => path problem).

I think the constraints about the given fraction are more restrictive, else your solution does not work (the comparison of fraction with multiplication can fail).

Great problem!
Some remarks:
 - I don't get what the (+ve) means in "All (+ve) rational numbers in the Number System ..."
 - You have two validators #6 (unless this breaks CG, this does not matter though).
 - In the 2nd validator #6, there is a typo line 4, where a "10" appears after the LR path.
A little problem  in the stub generator. You write 'H' in your loop, I think it's more 'N'

Thanks.
I found this S-B tree very interesting too, so studied on it and made this puzzle.
Thanks your detailed examination and feedback. The several problems are fixed.

Thanks your feedback. 
It is a property of the tree that a relatively short path sometimes can produce a very complicated fraction. So causes some "imbalance" feeling in the constraints.

The constraints are selected to ensure
1. the input path will be translated into two integers within constraint (can be handled by long int or double).
2. the input fraction will be translated in a path not longer than the specified string length

I prevent using big integers for p and q as input because it will produce a string much longer than the constraint.

Under this setting, coders should be able to translate the input into an output, and then reuse the output to translate back into the original input.

Whether the code can handle very big p and q as input is not tested in the puzzle. I think it is optional for coders to implement this part.

I agree my solution might fail under big p and q input. A simple solution is to us BIG INT to calculate the multiplication and compare. It will be slower than it is but will still fast enough to pass all tests.
Agree that this could be a difficulty to puzzle solvers. So that I added a note explaining how the row of numbers is related to the graph.
It's not easy to explain... I tried by myself but didn't find a clear way of doing it. Anyway, I understand it so most of people will be able to understand it :D
